Idiom (Sango): Beti ti mbênî ayeke ti nzönî
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Something that seems good at first but hides trouble underneath
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Everything that looks good is not always good
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from rural wisdom comparing shiny fruit to bitter taste
First Example Sentence: Ala yeke sôhô lo, mbênî ayeke ti nzönî, beti ti mbênî ayeke ti nzönî.
Second Example Sentence: Mo yeke hinga nzönî, lo tongana beti ti mbênî ayeke ti nzönî.
Third Example Sentence: Nzönî na lo yeke hinga, mbi yeke sôhô beti ti mbênî ayeke ti nzönî.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: God is in control, often used to accept misfortune
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Christianized expression from French missionary influence
First Example Sentence: Mbênî ti mbi ayeke la, mbi yeke sôhô: Nzapa a yeke na siriri.
Second Example Sentence: Tî mbi a tongana na mo, Nzapa a yeke na siriri.
Third Example Sentence: Lo ayeke kôso, mbeti ti lo a yeke na siriri.

Idiom (Sango): Kôzo ti sôhô lo ayeke la
First Example Sentence: Lo kôso mbênî ti mbi, kôzo ti sôhô lo ayeke la.
Second Example Sentence: Mo ayeke sôhô nzapa na mo, kôzo ti sôhô lo ayeke la.
Third Example Sentence: Tî lo ayeke sôhô, kôzo ti sôhô lo ayeke la.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To waste effort or talk to someone who won’t listen
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to calling into a cave and hearing no answer
First Example Sentence: Mbi yeke bila na nduru na lo, lo ayeke hinga te.
Second Example Sentence: Ala sôhô lo te, mbi yeke bila na nduru.
Third Example Sentence: Lo yeke bila na nduru tongana mbi a tene na lo.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: All things are under divine power
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in Central African Christian syncretism
First Example Sentence: Nzönî ayeke sô ti nzapa ayeke gï.
Second Example Sentence: Mbi yeke la, sô ti nzapa ayeke gï.
Third Example Sentence: Mo ayeke hinga, sô ti nzapa ayeke gï.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A small beginning that grows into something big
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Central African wisdom on growth and patience
First Example Sentence: Tî mbi ayeke la na yângâ, mbênî ti gbata nzönî.
Second Example Sentence: Nzönî ti lo a yeke mbi, mbênî ti gbata nzönî.
Third Example Sentence: Ala a tene mbi, mbênî ti gbata nzönî.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: One’s charm or talent shows naturally
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: They shine in their own way
First Example Sentence: Lo yeke hinga nzapa na lo, nzönî na yâ ti lo.
Second Example Sentence: Ala yeke tene lo nzönî na yâ ti lo.
Third Example Sentence: Nzönî na yâ ti lo ayeke mbi.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To pretend not to know or understand
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common idiom reflecting social avoidance behavior
First Example Sentence: Mbi tene na lo, lo tene na te.
Second Example Sentence: Lo yeke tene na te tongana mbi a sôhô lo.
Third Example Sentence: Lo tene na te sô mbi a hinga lo.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Plural subject with verb of state
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Everyone has their own way or character
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional belief in individuality within the community
First Example Sentence: Ala bî ti biani, lo tene tongana mo.
Second Example Sentence: Mo tene lo te, ala bî ti biani.
Third Example Sentence: Na sô ala yeke la, ala bî ti biani.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Clause with verb 'yeke' and prepositional phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To be clever or skilled with one’s hands
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to craftsmanship in Bangui artisanship
First Example Sentence: Lo yeke nginza na maboko, tongana mbi hinga lo ti bâa.
Second Example Sentence: Maboko ti lo a yeke nzönî, lo yeke nginza na maboko.
Third Example Sentence: Ala tene lo yeke nginza na maboko.
